title: Experimental Study of a Low-Voltage Pulsed Plasma Thruster for Nanosatellites. (arXiv:2211.01463v1 [physics.plasm-ph])
description: In this paper, three major objectives were pursued. To construct a coaxial pulsed plasma thruster operating with 10s to 100s of volts, to characterize the temporal evolution of the discharge parameters in this low-voltage operation scenario, and to study and understand the parasitic erosion of the tungsten cathode due to conventional cathode spots that were found at low local pressures when the first configurations of the coaxial PPT were tested. A coaxial PPT was designed, built, and tested. This design confirmed pulsed operation at discharge voltages less than 100 V across the plasma, achieving one of the project's aims. Using air as a propellant, the discharge generated a peak current of 10.4 kA at a mass flow rate of 2 mgs. The PPT cathode was imaged with an ICCD camera over a wide range of pressures, and the photos indicated "spotless" diffuse arc attachment to the cathode at higher local pressures, and the appearance of conventional cathode spots at lower local pressures. Two pressures were tested for lifetime erosion studies: a local pressure of 4 Torr saw an erosion rate of 9.93 micrograms per Coulomb, and a local pressure of 3.5e-5 Torr saw an increase in erosion rate of 411 percent at 40.785 micrograms per Coulomb.
dc:creator: Patrick Gresham, Brian Jeffers, Alexey Shashurin
